instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V0_G3H: What is PP3V0_G3H? PP3V0_G3H is a 3.0v power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PPVCCSA_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCSA_S0_CPU? Main power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. This is NOT shorted to ground if it has a low resistance â€“ this is a common mistake people make. A chip that requires high power at a low voltage like a CPU or GPU will have a low measured resistance to ground..
definitions.PPVCCIO_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCIO_S0_CPU? PPVCCIO_S0_CPU is a power rail responsible for powering the part of the CPU responsible for communicating with other portions of the machine prior to PPVCORE_S0_CPU being present and must be present before vcore, PPVCCIO_S0_CPU is present when the machine is in an on, RUNNING state. .
definitions.PP1V8_SUS: What is PP1V8_SUS? PP1V8_SUS is a 1.8v power rail active in a suspend state..
definitions.PP1V8_S4: What is PP1V8_S4? PP1V8_S4 is a 1.8v power rail when the machine is in an S4, suspend to disk state. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: So I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that is at 20V. 30mA and has all the G3H rails up to <SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H</SIGNAL>, which is at .01V and appears to have a 1.0 Ohm short to GND. Sadly thee liquid that I found was to the right of <CHIP>U1100</CHIP>. After looking at this rail rail. I see there only a few components and then <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>. I still need to look at where this rail comes from but I do not have a good feeling.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Fixed two corroded resistors above <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> and now have <SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H</SIGNAL>.

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> is .219V now and I am getting  3 ohms...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: great now <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> is 1V. This board is confusing the heck outta me

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Possibly accumulated crap under CPU.
Heat to 180-200 degrees, for 15-20s.
May need to do the same with SMC and <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Celsius, of course.
You only need to burn the crap, not to melt the balls.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Ah ok. Well I figured Celsius, so I tried it and no change.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: You should heat all BGA chips and finally pass the board through UC.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Ok, did that and no change. I can see crap under <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> which I assume is the PCH.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: You may need to reball it...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yeah, I think so. DO you know of anyone that has reballed one of these boards by hand? I do not have a BGA reball machine. I do have the stencil for this chip though.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Just to reiterate:  

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> is currently at 1.1V. This signal is created by <CHIP>U8200</CHIP> via pin 3. <CHIP>U8200</CHIP> is supplied by <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> on pin 2 which is supplied from <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>, which it has 3.3V. <CHIP>U8200</CHIP> is told to turn on by the power rail <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> which comes from pin 238 of <CHIP>U1100</CHIP>, which by no coincidence is also the only IC with foreign material under it from liquid damage. This signal is at 1.5V.
